h2.a: Behind the scenes of Lila, Chop!

header.aside: Behind the scenes of Lila, Chop!: the making of a recipe and how I learned to use the UNIX terminal command-line interface.

figure.figcaption: Building Lila, Chop! recipe articles in Terminal.

section.p: Welcome behind the scenes of Lila, Chop! Since first launching this recipe blog a year ago, I've been approached by several people telling me my recipes show how I make each dish, but not how I make each blog post. Eyebrows are always raised when I tell them I don't use any pre-existing template or graphical-interface tool, followed by tremendous curiosity and admiration that everything about the website is entirely unique and done in command-line. What – (gasp) – girls can UNIX? Well, thanks to K, who built the website from scratch and taught me how to run my own blog using command-line tools, yes: I can UNIX. (It's really not that scary.)

In this article I will take you through the making of a recipe and how I use the UNIX terminal command-line interface to post each blog article. From brain-storming flavour combinations to making a delightful mess in the kitchen, to food pornography – excuse me – I meant, photography, to writing and uploading each recipe post, I will show you snapshots of each step. Along the way you will see how I am inspired and supported by Lila; my little husky and muse, and K; the person who took the time to show me. (Both make excellent food-tasters, one provides better feedback than the other.) Without either of them Lila, Chop! would not have been possible. I dedicate this blog post to you, Kristaps — you make ships go.
